publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

seg.seg: ... the god Pūrṇabhadra, (looking at) his ornaments (which were) touching each other and made a (pleasant) noise,
... having illuminated the dwellings all around, (comes) to Bādhari the Brahmin
... he does not know the ‘top’, nor does he know the ‘falling from the top’
... Thus he spoke. || Having heard this, Bādhari the Brahmin, consoled
... (he says:) Who is it here, oh noble one, that knows the ‘top’? Or who knows the ‘falling from the top’?

... having placed before his eyes, as it were, the virtues of (the Buddha-god), the teacher, (he says:) || In the Devadatta [tune] || (Having seated himself) through his own wisdom on the diamond throne,
... he has attained (the state) of omniscience, having gained fame, the all-knowing one: gods...
... he knows (the ‘top’) and also the ‘falling from the top’. 1. || Thereupon Bādhari the Brahmin, (having heard about) the fame of the Buddha-god the teacher;
... with his face full, as it were, of ..., with mighty joy, a bent body with ... straight (turned) upwards
... oh noble one, whose name is Buddha, by the hearing of whose name I see, (among the beings lying) under the burden of Kleśas,
... the Buddha-god awakened indeed. || Pūrṇabhadra says: Whence (will) I (have) the ability,
... however, I will tell in short. Listen! There is, (in) the direction of the Himalaya mountains,
However, I will tell in short. Listen! (cf 57)
(on the banks of the Bhāgīrathī river, a lovely and beautiful city named Kapilavastu.) In this city now (there is) from the lineage of the Cakravartin king Ikṣvāku and the Gautama family
... there is an Indra-god (named Śuddhodana). For this king, Mahāmāyā, (the jewel) of queenship (gave birth to a son).
... in the hour of Vijaya, (endowed) with the thirty-two marks
... || In the Hetuphala [tune] || Just born, this one without (fear)

p.note: The commentary is adapted from 58.
MaitrHami 1, 14-15
(12) Na so muddhaṃ pajānāti, Muddhani muddhapāte vā
Kuhako so dhanatthiko, Ñāṇam tassa na vijjati ||
“He knows nothing about head(s). He is a deceitful (man), desiring money. He has no knowledge about head(s) or head-splitting.”
This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 14a11-15a8. See also 193-4.
The translation and the following commentary are adapted from 58.
mläṅk- is unknown to , but they assume an -n- infix formation of mälk- “to arrange”.
This leaf and the following () are discussed by and . Cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a11ff (cf. 18).
’s reading is incomplete, (o)stu, if correctly identified, seems to be a borrowing of TB ostuwa, plural of TB ost ‘house’, with an adaptation to the pattern of native TA waṣtu: waṣt.

Cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a18ff. Compare also the following passage from the Suttanipāta, ch. V. Pārāyanavagga (according to the references given above, section 1.4.5.3.), 1. Vatthugāthā, v. 986-987: “Seeing him terrified and miserable, a deity who desired his welfare going up to Bāvarī spoke these words:”
mälkärteṃ, cf. 161-180.

See 12: “Zu Zeile a 5: am Zeilenende gewiss zu A knā(naṣ\) – Ji knānaṣ! – zu ergänzen.” But in the transcription is, line 5: knā, line 6: (naṣ). The parentheses ( ) were arbitrarily taken away by Thomas.

12: ś[ś]aśmuraṣ\. The second [ś] on the original photograph is only a dim shadow; according to 281, the second ś was deleted intentionally in the original manuscript. devadattenaṃ is a stanza of 20 (5/5/5/5) + 22 (8/7/7) + 10 (5/5) + 15 (8/7) syllables. For the following speech, cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a28ff.
yomas: the sign ma on the original photograph is as clear as possible, but 8, n. 11 would prefer pa. The reading is confirmed by the parallel, MaitrHami 1, 14 b2.

smakk orto: 14: “den gebeugten Körper gleich[zeitig] nach oben ...” The 19th mark of the 32 marks of the Buddha is TA tsopats kārme kapśiññum (: a2) or tsopats smak kapśño (: b1), which are equivalent to the Skt. compound bṛhad-ṛju-kāyaḥ. Therefore, smak is somehow equal to Skt. ṛju-, which means “straight, right, upright, honest”, in German “gleich”. Thomas translates it first with “gleich[mässig]” and then turns it to “gleich[zeitig]”, which astonishes 58, who stress the huge difference between the two concepts. For the description of Badhari’s attitude, see MaitrHami 1, 14 b9ff.

yo: 9, n. 13 remarks that this is missing in Ji's transcription (). 58 counter that since on the original photograph only less than half of the syllable yo (?) is left, Thomas’ comment is rather too bold.
mälkärteṃ. 9, note 14: “steht in Ligatur, also nicht mit Ji malkarteṃ”, although his transcription would appear to be the same as ·malkarteṃ.
9 has p[t]āñkatt, while 58 regard the syllable tā of ptāñkatt as clear as possible and Thomas' [ ] as superfluous.
For the second half of this line, cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 b17ff.
Cf. MaitrHami 1, 15 a2-3.
hetuphalaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables. The end of this leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 1, 15 a8ff.

list.item: a1 /// purṇabhadre ñkät kälnmāṃ mläṅkmāṃ yetwes|yetwe|(s) a2 /// (o)stu ṣiraś lyalyukuräṣ bādhariṃ brāmnac a3 (träṅkäṣ) /// mā mrāc knānaṣ mā penu mrācis klālune knānaṣ a4 /// tämne we || täm kaklyuṣuräṣ bādhari brāhmaṃ tsātsärwu a5 /// (träṅkä)ṣ kus nu tṣaṃ mälkärteṃ mrāc knānaṣ kus pat nu mrācäṣ klālune knānaṣ|knā|(naṣ) a6 /// (käṣyā)p kāswoneytu yneśś oki śaśmuräṣ devadattenaṃ || # ṣñi knānmuneyo ; vajrāsanā|vajrā|(sanā) a7 %11 #1a %3 /// wram , puk kärsnāntāṃ ; yomäs kus ne , knānmune ; kälpo ñom klyu , puk knānmāṃ : #1b ñäktas|ñä|(ktas) a8 %8 #1c %6 /// knānaṣ ; mrācäṣ penu , letlune : 1 || #1d tmäṣ bādhari brāhmaṃ ptāñkät käṣyāp ñom b1 /// yo ypic oki akmalyo tampewātsäṃ kāckeyo nmosāṃ kapśañi smakk orto b2 /// (sä)m mälkärteṃ ptāñkät ñom ke ne näṣ ñom klyoṣluneyo kleśāṣiṃ āwaranyo klisoñcäs|kli|(soñcäs) b3 /// – ptāñkätt ats wāwrunt lkām || purṇabhadre träṅkäṣ k_ucäṣ ñi säm cämplune b4 /// ṣñikek_(TA)|ṣñikek nu waltsurā weñam päklyoṣ naṣ himavant ṣulis kälymeyaṃ|kälyme|(yaṃ) b5 /// (tā)m nu riyaṃ cakkravartṣi ikṣvākuy sarkäṣ gautam koträṣ|koträ|(ṣ) b6 /// w(l)āñ(kä)t (n)aṣ cami nu lānt mahāmāyā lātsuneṣiṃ b7 (ñemi) /// traṃ • vijai muhurtaṃ • taryāk we pi lakṣaṇäsyo b8 /// – || hetuphalaṃ || # täm tatmu säm , sne #1a

This fragment contains part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami I, 14a11-15a8. See also [[Pinault 1999]]: 193-4.

The translation and the following commentary are adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 58.

Translations from [[Peyrot, ToSu]]
Lines Translation Pages
b4 However, I will tell in short. Listen! (cf [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 57) 219


  • line a2, translation: [[Carling, DThTA]]: 118 has “completely” for “all around” (TI)
  • [[Adams 2012a]] (28) calls this fragment "A-YQ1.3 1/2" and has the transcription a2 (o)stu ṣiraś lyalyakuräṣ. –Martin (Mon, 2015-08-17, 22:23:22 (CEST))
  • a1. kälnmāṃ mläṅkmāṃ yetwes "jewellery put on that was resounding" or "jewellery that put together [was] resounding" –Hannes (Tue, 2015-09-15, 16:39:25 (CEST))

a1 ... the god Pūrṇabhadra, (looking at) his ornaments (which were) touching each other and made a (pleasant) noise, a2 ... having illuminated the dwellings all around, (comes) to Bādhari the Brahmin a3 ... he does not know the ‘top’, nor does he know the ‘falling from the top’ a4 ... Thus he spoke. || Having heard this, Bādhari the Brahmin, consoled a5 ... (he says:) Who is it here, oh noble one, that knows the ‘top’? Or who knows the ‘falling from the top’? a6 ... having placed before his eyes, as it were, the virtues of (the Buddha-god), the teacher, (he says:) || In the Devadatta [tune] || (Having seated himself) through his own wisdom on the diamond throne, a7 ... he has attained (the state) of omniscience, having gained fame, the all-knowing one: gods... a8 ... he knows (the ‘top’) and also the ‘falling from the top’. 1. || Thereupon Bādhari the Brahmin, (having heard about) the fame of the Buddha-god the teacher; b1 ... with his face full, as it were, of ..., with mighty joy, a bent body with ... straight (turned) upwards b2 ... oh noble one, whose name is Buddha, by the hearing of whose name I see, (among the beings lying) under the burden of Kleśas, b3 ... the Buddha-god awakened indeed. || Pūrṇabhadra says: Whence (will) I (have) the ability, b4 ... however, I will tell in short. Listen! There is, (in) the direction of the Himalaya mountains, b5 (on the banks of the Bhāgīrathī river, a lovely and beautiful city named Kapilavastu.) In this city now (there is) from the lineage of the Cakravartin king Ikṣvāku and the Gautama family b6 ... there is an Indra-god (named Śuddhodana). For this king, Mahāmāyā, (the jewel) of queenship (gave birth to a son). b7 ... in the hour of Vijaya, (endowed) with the thirty-two marks b8 ... || In the Hetuphala [tune] || Just born, this one without (fear)

a1. This leaf and the following ([[YQ I.9]]) are discussed by [[Pinault 1990]] and [[Thomas 1991]]. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a11ff (cf. [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 18).

a3. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a18ff. Compare also the following passage from the Suttanipāta, ch. V. Pārāyanavagga (according to the references given above, section 1.4.5.3.), 1. Vatthugāthā, v. 986-987: “Seeing him terrified and miserable, a deity who desired his welfare going up to Bāvarī spoke these words:”

(12) Na so muddhaṃ pajānāti, Muddhani muddhapāte vā

Kuhako so dhanatthiko, Ñāṇam tassa na vijjati ||

“He knows nothing about head(s). He is a deceitful (man), desiring money. He has no knowledge about head(s) or head-splitting.”

a6. [[Thomas 1991]]: 12: ś[ś]aśmuraṣ\. The second [ś] on the original photograph is only a dim shadow; according to [[Schmidt KT 1999b]]: 281, the second ś was deleted intentionally in the original manuscript. devadattenaṃ is a stanza of 20 (5/5/5/5) + 22 (8/7/7) + 10 (5/5) + 15 (8/7) syllables. For the following speech, cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 a28ff.

a7. yomas: the sign ma on the original photograph is as clear as possible, but [[Thomas 1991]]: 8, n. 11 would prefer pa. The reading is confirmed by the parallel, MaitrHami 1, 14 b2.

b1. yo: [[Thomas 1991]]: 9, n. 13 remarks that this is missing in Ji's transcription ([[Ji 1983]]). [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 58 counter that since on the original photograph only less than half of the syllable yo (?) is left, Thomas’ comment is rather too bold.

b2. mälkärteṃ. [[Thomas 1991]]: 9, note 14: “steht in Ligatur, also nicht mit Ji malkarteṃ”, although his transcription would appear to be the same as [[Ji 1983]] ·malkarteṃ.

b3. For the second half of this line, cf. MaitrHami 1, 14 b17ff.

b7. Cf. MaitrHami 1, 15 a2-3.

b8. hetuphalaṃ: a stanza of 4 x 18 (7/7/4) syllables. The end of this leaf corresponds to MaitrHami 1, 15 a8ff.

a1 /// [purṇa]bhadre ñ_k_a_t _k_alnmāṃ _m_l_aṅkmāṃ yetwe- a2 /// stu ṣiraśä\ lyalyuku_r_a_ṣ\ bādhariṃ brāmnacä\ a3 /// [mā mrā]cä\ knāna_ṣ\ mā penu mrāci_s\ klālune knāna_ṣ\ a4 /// _t_amne we || _t_am kaklyuṣu_r_a_ṣ\ bādhari brāhmaṃ tsāt_s_arwu a5 /// – _ṣ\ kus nu tṣaṃ _m_a_l_k_arteṃ mrācä\ knāna_ṣ\ kus pat nu mrācä_ṣ\ klālune knā- a6 /// [p kā]swoneytu yneśś oki śaśmu_r_a_ṣ\ devadattenaṃ || ṣñi knānmuneyo vajrā- a7 /// [wra]m puk _k_arsnāntāṃ yo_m_a_s\ kus ne knānmune _k_alpo ño_m\ klyu pu_k\ knānmāṃ : ñä- a8 /// [kn]āna_ṣ\ mrācäṣ penu letlune : 1 || _t_m_a_ṣ\ bādhari brāhmaṃ ptāñ_k_a_t _k_aṣyāp ño_m\ b1 /// [yo] ypicä\ oki akmalyo tampewāt_s_aṃ kāckeyo nmosāṃ kapśañi smakk orto b2 /// [m] _m_a_l_k_arteṃ ptāñ_kä_t\ ñom ke ne nä_ṣ\ ño_m\ klyoṣluneyo kleśāṣiṃ āwaranyo kli- b3 /// – ptāñ_k_att at_s\ wāwrun_t\ lkā_m\ || purṇabhadre t_r_aṅ_k_a_ṣ\ k_ucä_ṣ\ ñi _s_am cämplune b4 /// [ṣñi]kek nu waltsurā weña_m _p_aklyo_ṣ\ na_ṣ\ himavan_t\ ṣuli_s _k_alyme- b5 /// – m nu riyaṃ cakkravartṣi ikṣvākuy sar_k_a_ṣ\ gauta_m\ kot_r_a- b6 /// [w](·)āñ(·)·[t] (·)a_ṣ\ cami nu lān_t\ mahāmāyā lātsuneṣiṃ b7 /// [traṃ] • vijai muhurtaṃ • taryāk we pi lakṣaṇäsyo b8 /// – || hetuphalaṃ || _t_am tatmu _s_a_m\ sne

The commentary is adapted from [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 58.

a1. mläṅk- is unknown to [[Ji et al. 1998]], but they assume an -n- infix formation of mälk- “to arrange”.

a2. [[Thomas 1991]]’s reading is incomplete, (o)stu, if correctly identified, seems to be a borrowing of TB ostuwa, plural of TB ost ‘house’, with an adaptation to the pattern of native TA waṣtu: waṣt.

a5. mälkärteṃ, cf. [[Pinault 1993]]: 161-180.

a5-6. See [[Thomas 1991]]: 12: “Zu Zeile a 5: am Zeilenende gewiss zu A knā(naṣ\) – Ji knānaṣ! – zu ergänzen.” But in [[Ji 1983]] the transcription is, line 5: knā, line 6: (naṣ). The parentheses ( ) were arbitrarily taken away by Thomas.

b1. smakk orto: [[Thomas 1991]]: 14: “den gebeugten Körper gleich[zeitig] nach oben ...” The 19th mark of the 32 marks of the Buddha is TA tsopats kārme kapśiññum ([[YQ II.5]]: a2) or tsopats smak kapśño ([[YQ II.10]]: b1), which are equivalent to the Skt. compound bṛhad-ṛju-kāyaḥ. Therefore, smak is somehow equal to Skt. ṛju-, which means “straight, right, upright, honest”, in German “gleich”. Thomas translates it first with “gleich[mässig]” and then turns it to “gleich[zeitig]”, which astonishes [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 58, who stress the huge difference between the two concepts. For the description of Badhari’s attitude, see MaitrHami 1, 14 b9ff.

b3. [[Thomas 1991]]: 9 has p[t]āñkatt, while [[Ji et al. 1998]]: 58 regard the syllable tā of ptāñkatt as clear as possible and Thomas' [ ] as superfluous.

div.p: • line a2, translation: <citedRange>118</citedRange></bibl> has “completely” for “all around” (TI)</li><li><bibl><title corresp="ref:adams2012a"/></bibl> (28) calls this fragment "A-YQ1.3 1/2" and has the transcription <ref type="ms" target="__a2"/> <hi>(o)stu ṣiraś lyaly<span style="color: red;">a</span>kuräṣ</hi>. –Martin (Mon, 2015-08-17, 22:23:22 (CEST))</li><li><ref type="ms" target="__a1."/><hi>kälnmāṃ mläṅkmāṃ yetwes</hi> "jewellery put on that was resounding" or "jewellery that put together [was] resounding" –Hannes (Tue, 2015-09-15, 16:39:25 (CEST)) </li></ul></p></project_comment>
